awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: CAS: A Novel Approach for Achieving Scale in Direct Air Carbon Capture
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in potentially contributing to the creation of a viable gigaton-scale Direct Air CO2 (carbon dioxide) Capture (DAC) technology. The technology could be a key pillar in preventing the worst effects of climate change. For over a century, humanity has emitted billions of tons of CO2 into the atmosphere each year. As more CO2 has accumulated in the atmosphere trapping the sun’s rays, Earth’s temperature has continued to rise. According to the Bipartisan Policy Center, gigaton-scale DAC stands to support the creation of a trillion-dollar industry in the United States and underpin the development of 3 million jobs.
		 	 	 		
This project is based on a novel DAC design addressing two key hurdles to achieving the scale needed to effectively offset CO2-caused climate change: cost to build infrastructure and energy to run processes. The system injects carbon capture fluid with a monoethanolamine (MEA) spray and removes that spray with an exhaust particle separating centrifuge. Through this hollow design, it not only saves on building costs, but may be poised to save on ongoing energy costs. Energy cost in a carbon capture contactor is a function of pressure drop or drag. The company's hypothesis is that a centrifuge is significantly more aerodynamic than the honeycomb-like filling currently used in contactors.  The energy savings can translate into a system with significantly lower pressure drop and, therefore, lower ongoing energy costs to run. The program is organized into research objectives that investigate each area of technical risk. The first objective is calculating the optimal fluid particle size for capturing carbon dioxide from the air and optimizing the MEA operating range within the proposed system through Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) and lab testing.  The second objective is determining the relationship between the fan and centrifuge through physical prototyping.  The third objective is designing the facility shape itself though a mix of CFD and physical prototyping.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our SBIR Phase I sought to develop, validate and improve a significantly more scalable and efficient solution for direct air capture (DAC). While climate models agree DAC must scale to capturing 10 gigatons of CO2 per year, CO2 makes up only .04% of atmospheric air.  This diffuse concentration presents a core physical challenge of processing immense amounts of air each year as efficiently as possible. Put simply, DAC is an airflow problem. After a literature and IP review, we identified a notable industry shortcoming in that all existing DAC systems have a similar architecture for airflow: a filter or other solid media that creates resistance to airflow. The construction of said filters vary from solid sorbents, to packing media sprayed with a solvent, to natural materials like limestone arranged on trays. For DAC based on active airflow, the act of running air past said media creates significant air resistance, while also underpinning kinetic inefficiencies that lead to higher regeneration costs.  In most cases, the filters themselves carry significant up front and maintenance costs, which compound as the systems move towards gigaton scale.

Our SBIR Phase I sought to evaluate the feasibility of an alternate architecture principally optimized for airflow efficiency and scalability, without compromising on efficacy of CO2 capture. We proposed developing a contactor in which air is pulled into the system, a concurrent spray of solvent is injected into a hollow space with no physical media to resist airflow, and the spray is separated from the airflow at exhaust for reuse. Our SBIR I asked the question: can a spray perform as effectively as a solid media at capturing CO2, and can we overcome the core technical risks of recapturing said spray completely, without driving costs through separation and fan energy. In addition, we sought to address reviewer questions on solvent evaporation.

We developed a system prototype, referred to as GigaDAC ®, demonstrating solvent spray is comparably effective as solid media at capturing CO2, and that said spray can be completely captured from the airflow at significantly lower energy demand than solid filter systems. We further established that a spray creates a more kinetic interaction with CO2 than current capture media, enabling the use of weaker solvents that are less energy-intensive to regenerate.   We divided our work into three phases: phase 1.) initial proof of concept prototype planning and operation 2.) system optimization through prototyping and computational fluid dynamic modeling 3.) establishing per-ton capture cost. 

Our results indicate a total system pressure drop of 30PA, equating to 21.63 kWh per ton for fan operation with MEA. Our pumping energy for maintaining solvent spray in the system is calculated at 1.8 kWh per ton of CO2 captured, and regenerating DEA or MEA is known to be 785 kWh (DEA) – 849 (MEA) kWh per ton. Working with suppliers, we calculated an amortized cost of $5.06 per ton to build the facility for MEA. Factoring in 75kWh for known geologic sequestration demand, an energy cost of .08 per kWh, the system developed from the SBIR phase I is likely to achieve a capture cost of at $80.90 (MEA) and $89.74 (DEA) per ton at scale.

After significant prototyping and iteration, we developed a modular system to maximize ease and cost-effectiveness of deployment. These modules are based on standard 40ft, high-cube shipping container architecture. With capture capacity of 1,000 kilotons per year per module, we can build 20,000 kilotons of capture capacity per acre. 10 gigatons of capture capacity would require 500,000 acres, an area that could fit four times over into a space the size of Yellowstone National Park. If deployed over the next 20 years, the container unit deployment would be the equivalent of just 1.2% of current ocean freight container movement.

With efficient airflow, effective kinetics, low material costs and ease of deployment — achieving gigaton-scale DAC will be achieved.  Technical risks remain with further scale and optimization of the system. We consider those risks primarily to be facility height. Existing DAC systems are between 5-10 meters in contact distance, allowing resonance time to lower CO2 concentrations between 50-80%, greater than the ~20% in our two-meter system. Demonstrating our system will achieve similar metrics at similar scale is yet unresolved and warrants further study.

Looking forward, we are building a business model in which the GigaDAC contactor units can be profitably sold to DAC companies using other solvents, and our company can earn revenue selling and maintaining said units. Whether operating DAC facilities ourselves and monetizing offsets and tax credits, or selling contactor units to DAC companies using other solvents — we are gearing our core underlying business to profit from the success of Direct Air Capture in achieving gigaton scale.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/23/2024
Modified by: Harrison Rice
